REVIEW: The Executioner and Her Way of Life            Goto page 1, 2, 3  Next Note: this is the discussion thread for this article     Anime News Network Forum Index -> Site-related -> Talkback    View previous topic :: View next topic     Author Message        L'Imperatore    Joined: 24 Mar 2014 		    Posts: 514       Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 10:32 am            Same here, James. When Menou murdered this random isekai-ed dude, I'm sold        Back to top                  dm   Subscriber   Joined: 24 Sep 2010 		    Posts: 966       Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 10:44 am            The train-wreck scene was a great cap to the third episode, but the thing that caught my attention was when, in parting in the train car, Akari said "I don't want to be left alone again!", and Menou paused at the door to wonder, "Again?"   I wonder if this entire story maybe isn't Akari's first trip through this tale.      Back to top                  Rogueywon    Joined: 01 May 2011 		    Posts: 180       Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 11:03 am            My take on the light novels (the ones out in English at least) was that they're ambitious and high concept, but prone to getting muddled - so much stuff gong on to juggle - and dragged down by writing that was never really more than fair-to-middling. There's also an occasional tendancy towards excessive lore-dumping. The question is whether the adaptation can overcome those faults.    So far, it's looking good. The first three episodes definitely surpass the source in places.      Back to top                  RenimLS    Joined: 26 Mar 2014 		    Posts: 70 		    Location: North America 		        Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 11:17 am            I rather appreciate that the show is sometimes being more vague or less forthcoming on details than the LN.   It seems the show is set to really only cover them when it's necessary, which the LN tends to reveal more of its hand before it's actually necessary.  The way the LN introduces Akari you're actually in her headspace and get her thoughts on things before Menou appears.  spoiler[Which serves as a flag for the readers as her feelings and thoughts do not match up well with her behavior after meeting Menou], but it wasn't really necessary to have to go there.      Back to top                  zensunni    Joined: 05 Mar 2010 		    Posts: 1279       Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 11:19 am              dm wrote:    The train-wreck scene was a great cap to the third episode, but the thing that caught my attention was when, in parting in the train car, Akari said "I don't want to be left alone again!", and Menou paused at the door to wonder, "Again?"   I wonder if this entire story maybe isn't Akari's first trip through this tale.            Exactly! There was a huge hint there that Akari has either been through this all before OR her life in Japan featured abandonment and loneliness to spare. Perhaps this could have something to do with the dreams that Menou has about being in a classroom in Japan with her best friend who has Akari's outline waving at her? Is it possible that Menou is also not a native of this world, but also an otherworlder with a pure concept that is just as dangerous as Akari's?    And the train wreck scene at the end was NOT the first indication that Akari's pure concept had come into play during the episode. There was a moment, shortly before Akari interupted Menou's fight with the Red Knight when she attacked and then was back in position to attack again and had a 'Whoa... that was weird' reaction, and then the same basic thing happened in the fight between Momo and the Princess, and one of them said something like "That was disconcerting..."   And, technically, the train wreck scene was  Menou's imagination of what might have happened... at least that's my take on it. If we see the scene from Akari's point of view at some point we'll know for sure I guess.   There is one thing I wonder about with the crusade the Church has against Otherworlders with Pure Concepts. If ALL Pure Concepts eventually corrupt the person, how did their society get influenced so strongly by Japanese culture and language? It seems like, if the otherworlders were always so unstable, they wouldn't have had the type of impact on the world that they did to influence so much of their culture. This says to me that the church is actually reacting to the few extreme cases... the Great Human Errors... and eliminating ALL otherworlders in order to prevent any more catastrophes of that magnitude, when it is possible that some otherworlders might be able to remain stable with their Pure Concepts and not lose control.   I'm guessing that is the direction Menou's thoughts will be heading in the story at least... since Akari seems to be a girl that has already lived through some heavy stuff and maintained a positive outlook on life and might be the type that won't appear to be corrupted by repeated use of her powers, or suspected repeated use of her powers since Menou won't really know that they were used since it will be to save her life every time.      Back to top                  Aerodynamic41    Joined: 20 Oct 2015 		    Posts: 136       Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 11:39 am            I absolutely love the LN and the adaptation is looking great so far. I think the red knight didn't feel as dangerous as it was in the LN but that's a minor quibble. From the opening and the pacing, it looks like the anime will adapt until Volume 2. I'm really excited to see how the anime will depict spoiler[Akari's real personality].      Back to top                  thadec    Joined: 02 Apr 2022 		    Posts: 37       Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 11:45 am            Proposing that James Beckett not be allowed to review any isekai titles in the future, or really shonen shows in general. It seems that Beckett has a real disdain towards the target audience - or at least what that audience likes and why - and will not be objective.      Back to top                  FilthyCasual    Joined: 01 Jun 2015 		    Posts: 1692       Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 11:46 am            It's nice to have a refreshingly Light Novel Energy LN adaptation.  Dead Detective did its best, but the production values and plotting crumpled; fingers crossed this one goes the distance.  Presumably Akari will be something other than Nice, Existent, and Increasingly Down Bad once she gets shipped off to church.     Menou and Momo are great, though.  Especially poor Momo, doomed to lose to BSS.      Back to top                  dm   Subscriber   Joined: 24 Sep 2010 		    Posts: 966       Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 1:00 pm              zensunni wrote:    And the train wreck scene at the end was NOT the first indication that Akari's pure concept had come into play during the episode. There was a moment, shortly before Akari interupted Menou's fight with the Red Knight when she attacked and then was back in position to attack again and had a 'Whoa... that was weird' reaction, and then the same basic thing happened in the fight between Momo and the Princess, and one of them said something like "That was disconcerting..."            I interpreted the train-wreck scene at the end as the explanation for the time-stutter in the fight with the Red Knight (and the "simultaneous" scene between Momo and the Princess) --- that was the moment Akari reset the timeline to.     Quote:    And, technically, the train wreck scene was  Menou's imagination of what might have happened... at least that's my take on it. If we see the scene from Akari's point of view at some point we'll know for sure I guess.            Given that I think Menou's vision provides an explanation for the time-stutter earlier in the episode, I interpret it as a memory of the original timeline.      Back to top                  TarsTarkas    Joined: 20 Dec 2007 		    Posts: 5327 		    Location: Virginia, United States 		        Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 1:36 pm            I like this series and I like the characters.  So looking at this one as a must see to the end.  I wonder if the anime adaptation will beat out the english light novels.   About Menou, while the anime shows her killing someone who probably deserves to die, we must remember spoiler[she and her group kill everyone who has that power/skill.  Guilt or innocence doesn't matter.  People who want to have normal lives within soceity and don't use their power/skill, are still hunted down and killed.  If you have been isekai'd, they will search for you, and they will kill you.  So even if you choose to be a good person and not use your power, you will still be killed.]  So Menou is a problematic character.  You can sympathize with her for her upbringing (brainwashing?) and despise her for her actions.   I like Momo too and can understand why she is the way she is.  Like Menou too.  Much discussion could be had on who is ultimately responsible and if really any justice can be had.  Probably not.      Back to top                  Nev999    Joined: 05 Aug 2021 		    Posts: 31       Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 1:37 pm              thadec wrote:    Proposing that James Beckett not be allowed to review any isekai titles in the future, or really shonen shows in general. It seems that Beckett has a real disdain towards the target audience - or at least what that audience likes and why - and will not be objective.            And I propose that he should be allowed to review whatever he wants, which I imagine will continue to happen. I've been following ANN for a while, and considering he really liked JJK (way more than I did), did super in-depth adoring reviews on AoT (which personally just allowed me to see that the show was continuing not to be my thing at all but I admired his passion) and his criticisms of Demon Slayer were pretty mild, it's just that fanbase is ridiculous, I never got the impression he doesn't like shonen or doesn't fall into its audience at all. And he's suited just fine for this series, as the reason people are interested in THIS show is because it's offering a bit of a twist on the isekai premise, and that seems to be what he was hooked by as well. This review focused on whether the show itself held together beyond that initial hook, and offered a fair assessment.   And honestly, considering you criticized the main character of this show and its fandom despite admitting not even watching the first episode in the Premiere thread, I don't think you personally have much room to talk about how it's bad to approach something with preconceived notions or disdain for the target audience.   For me, I think what will make or break this show is how Akari holds up as a character, and if her deal and her relationship with Menou deepens wants she finds out about Menou's hidden agenda. If she's what she appears on the surface, or they're just leaning on tropes with her, the central relationship won't be dynamic enough to carry the show, so I'm also hoping that hint about not wanting to be left behind means we'll get some good character writing and reason to root for this dynamic. There were quite a few moments in the eps that made me roll my eyes, but enough mystery and intrigue and potential in the plot I'm willing to keep going. Plus, I'm trash for girls being cool action heroes and gay with each other, I won't lie.      Back to top                  Florete    Joined: 21 Jan 2018 		    Posts: 259       Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 3:06 pm            The novels of this series are what got me to start taking notes on what I read, just to make sure I can keep track of all that is and has been going on.   Funny how, from what I'm seeing, the critics are liking this more than the fans. Perhaps seeing their precious self-insert potato-kun get a murder done on him was triggering.      Back to top                  Thesarum    Joined: 25 Mar 2022 		    Posts: 14       Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 4:40 pm            Serious bad vibes from Mother Superior. Quite aside from the obviously ominous name of "Archbishop Orwell" and the fact that any time a western church (i.e. Catholic/Anglican in its structure and iconography) is depicted in anime they're generally bad news. There's a whole pile of secrets awaiting us (and, by the looks of things, Menou) there. I think the fact that Menou will have her faith in the church challenged is fairly obvious. It'd be more of a twist if she didn't and it was just a straight up choice of betraying them for Akari.   Akari seems to have her share of secrets too, which is great. The bubbly crushing-on-Menou personality is plenty fun, but could outstay its welcome fairly easily.   Enjoying this so far, and there's plenty of promise.      Back to top                  Covnam    Joined: 31 May 2005 		    Posts: 2871       Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 10:18 pm              Quote:    we all know that Menou is going to eventually start to question her role as Akari's murderer            That's the most predicable thing to happen (leading to her not trying to kill (or save as needed) Akari, and while I think that's probably what will happen, I hope the story goes in a different direction. I'm enjoying it so far, but not interested in seeing the usual tropes, so fingers crossed   Stopping the train that way was odd. The engine was going full tilt, but instead of shutting off the engine, they just slowed the train by using a magic net (which, at that speed, probably would have caused the middle and rear cars of the train to derail at best (unless all the cars were also slowed by the magic?)) and somehow that caused it to turn off?      zensunni wrote:      And the train wreck scene at the end was NOT the first indication that Akari's pure concept had come into play during the episode. There was a moment, shortly before Akari interupted Menou's fight with the Red Knight when she attacked and then was back in position to attack again and had a 'Whoa... that was weird' reaction, and then the same basic thing happened in the fight between Momo and the Princess, and one of them said something like "That was disconcerting..."            I'm guessing those two moments are for the same event and are proof that time was rewound from the wreck we see at the end of the episode back to that point.      Back to top                  DRosencraft    Joined: 27 Apr 2010 		    Posts: 529       Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 11:10 pm              TarsTarkas wrote:    I like this series and I like the characters.  So looking at this one as a must see to the end.  I wonder if the anime adaptation will beat out the english light novels.   About Menou, while the anime shows her killing someone who probably deserves to die, we must remember spoiler[she and her group kill everyone who has that power/skill.  Guilt or innocence doesn't matter.  People who want to have normal lives within soceity and don't use their power/skill, are still hunted down and killed. You can sympathize with her for her upbringing (brainwashing?) and despise her for her actions.   I like Momo too and can understand why she is the way she is.  Like Menou too.  Much discussion could be had on who is ultimately responsible and if really any justice can be had.  Probably not.            I've definitely already seen some people making that same mistake, if you want to call it a mistake, of not recognizing that Menou is at a minimum far more complicated than "hero stopping monsters" many want to paint her as out the gate. I haven't read the novels, but it's really obvious there are only a few directions things could be heading, an only a couple of them let her stay in the realm of any sort of heroic character - flawed or otherwise.    My sense of the "justice" issue is that, as it often turns out, it is a matter of stop diffing a deeper pit once you realize what's going on. My guess is that one or the other or both by the end will recognize that philosophy too late, or have given up on it despite realizing it. I've been following ANN for a while, and considering he really liked JJK (way more than I did), did super in-depth adoring reviews on AoT (which personally just allowed me to see that the show was continuing not to be my thing at all but I admired his passion) and his criticisms of Demon Slayer were pretty mild, it's just that fanbase is ridiculous, I never got the impression he doesn't like shonen or doesn't fall into its audience at all. And he's suited just fine for this series, as the reason people are interested in THIS show is because it's offering a bit of a twist on the isekai premise, and that seems to be what he was hooked by as well. This review focused on whether the show itself held together beyond that initial hook, and offered a fair assessment.   And honestly, considering you criticized the main character of this show and its fandom despite admitting not even watching the first episode in the Premiere thread, I don't think you personally have much room to talk about how it's bad to approach something with preconceived notions or disdain for the target audience.   For me, I think what will make or break this show is how Akari holds up as a character, and if her deal and her relationship with Menou deepens wants she finds out about Menou's hidden agenda. If she's what she appears on the surface, or they're just leaning on tropes with her, the central relationship won't be dynamic enough to carry the show, so I'm also hoping that hint about not wanting to be left behind means we'll get some good character writing and reason to root for this dynamic. There were quite a few moments in the eps that made me roll my eyes, but enough mystery and intrigue and potential in the plot I'm willing to keep going. Plus, I'm trash for girls being cool action heroes and gay with each other, I won't lie.      Back to top                  Florete    Joined: 21 Jan 2018 		    Posts: 259       Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 3:06 pm            The novels of this series are what got me to start taking notes on what I read, just to make sure I can keep track of all that is and has been going on.   Funny how, from what I'm seeing, the critics are liking this more than the fans. Perhaps seeing their precious self-insert potato-kun get a murder done on him was triggering.      Back to top                  Thesarum    Joined: 25 Mar 2022 		    Posts: 14       Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 4:40 pm            Serious bad vibes from Mother Superior. Quite aside from the obviously ominous name of "Archbishop Orwell" and the fact that any time a western church (i.e. Catholic/Anglican in its structure and iconography) is depicted in anime they're generally bad news. There's a whole pile of secrets awaiting us (and, by the looks of things, Menou) there. I think the fact that Menou will have her faith in the church challenged is fairly obvious. It'd be more of a twist if she didn't and it was just a straight up choice of betraying them for Akari.   Akari seems to have her share of secrets too, which is great. The bubbly crushing-on-Menou personality is plenty fun, but could outstay its welcome fairly easily.   Enjoying this so far, and there's plenty of promise.      Back to top                  Covnam    Joined: 31 May 2005 		    Posts: 2871       Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 10:18 pm              Quote:    we all know that Menou is going to eventually start to question her role as Akari's murderer            That's the most predicable thing to happen (leading to her not trying to kill (or save as needed) Akari, and while I think that's probably what will happen, I hope the story goes in a different direction. I'm enjoying it so far, but not interested in seeing the usual tropes, so fingers crossed   Stopping the train that way was odd. The engine was going full tilt, but instead of shutting off the engine, they just slowed the train by using a magic net (which, at that speed, probably would have caused the middle and rear cars of the train to derail at best (unless all the cars were also slowed by the magic?)) and somehow that caused it to turn off?      zensunni wrote:      And the train wreck scene at the end was NOT the first indication that Akari's pure concept had come into play during the episode. There was a moment, shortly before Akari interupted Menou's fight with the Red Knight when she attacked and then was back in position to attack again and had a 'Whoa... that was weird' reaction, and then the same basic thing happened in the fight between Momo and the Princess, and one of them said something like "That was disconcerting..."            I'm guessing those two moments are for the same event and are proof that time was rewound from the wreck we see at the end of the episode back to that point.      Back to top                  DRosencraft    Joined: 27 Apr 2010 		    Posts: 529       Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 11:10 pm              TarsTarkas wrote:    I like this series and I like the characters.  So looking at this one as a must see to the end.  I wonder if the anime adaptation will beat out the english light novels.   About Menou, while the anime shows her killing someone who probably deserves to die, we must remember spoiler[she and her group kill everyone who has that power/skill.  Guilt or innocence doesn't matter.  People who want to have normal lives within soceity and don't use their power/skill, are still hunted down and killed.  If you have been isekai'd, they will search for you, and they will kill you.  So even if you choose to be a good person and not use your power, you will still be killed.]  So Menou is a problematic character.  You can sympathize with her for her upbringing (brainwashing?) and despise her for her actions.   I like Momo too and can understand why she is the way she is.  Like Menou too.  Much discussion could be had on who is ultimately responsible and if really any justice can be had.  Probably not.            I've definitely already seen some people making that same mistake, if you want to call it a mistake, of not recognizing that Menou is at a minimum far more complicated than "hero stopping monsters" many want to paint her as out the gate. I haven't read the novels, but it's really obvious there are only a few directions things could be heading, an only a couple of them let her stay in the realm of any sort of heroic character - flawed or otherwise.    My sense of the "justice" issue is that, as it often turns out, it is a matter of stop diffing a deeper pit once you realize what's going on. My guess is that one or the other or both by the end will recognize that philosophy too late, or have given up on it despite realizing it. REVIEW: The Executioner and Her Way of Life            Goto page 1, 2, 3  Next Note: this is the discussion thread for this article     Anime News Network Forum Index -> Site-related -> Talkback    View previous topic :: View next topic     Author Message        L'Imperatore    Joined: 24 Mar 2014 		    Posts: 514       Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 10:32 am            Same here, James. When Menou murdered this random isekai-ed dude, I'm sold        Back to top                  dm   Subscriber   Joined: 24 Sep 2010 		    Posts: 966       Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 10:44 am            The train-wreck scene was a great cap to the third episode, but the thing that caught my attention was when, in parting in the train car, Akari said "I don't want to be left alone again!", and Menou paused at the door to wonder, "Again?"   I wonder if this entire story maybe isn't Akari's first trip through this tale.      Back to top                  Rogueywon    Joined: 01 May 2011 		    Posts: 180       Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 11:03 am            My take on the light novels (the ones out in English at least) was that they're ambitious and high concept, but prone to getting muddled - so much stuff gong on to juggle - and dragged down by writing that was never really more than fair-to-middling. There's also an occasional tendancy towards excessive lore-dumping. The question is whether the adaptation can overcome those faults.    So far, it's looking good. The first three episodes definitely surpass the source in places.      Back to top                  RenimLS    Joined: 26 Mar 2014 		    Posts: 70 		    Location: North America 		        Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 11:17 am            I rather appreciate that the show is sometimes being more vague or less forthcoming on details than the LN.   It seems the show is set to really only cover them when it's necessary, which the LN tends to reveal more of its hand before it's actually necessary.  The way the LN introduces Akari you're actually in her headspace and get her thoughts on things before Menou appears.  spoiler[Which serves as a flag for the readers as her feelings and thoughts do not match up well with her behavior after meeting Menou], but it wasn't really necessary to have to go there.      Back to top                  zensunni    Joined: 05 Mar 2010 		    Posts: 1279       Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 11:19 am              dm wrote:    The train-wreck scene was a great cap to the third episode, but the thing that caught my attention was when, in parting in the train car, Akari said "I don't want to be left alone again!", and Menou paused at the door to wonder, "Again?"   I wonder if this entire story maybe isn't Akari's first trip through this tale.            Exactly! There was a huge hint there that Akari has either been through this all before OR her life in Japan featured abandonment and loneliness to spare. Perhaps this could have something to do with the dreams that Menou has about being in a classroom in Japan with her best friend who has Akari's outline waving at her? Is it possible that Menou is also not a native of this world, but also an otherworlder with a pure concept that is just as dangerous as Akari's?    And the train wreck scene at the end was NOT the first indication that Akari's pure concept had come into play during the episode. There was a moment, shortly before Akari interupted Menou's fight with the Red Knight when she attacked and then was back in position to attack again and had a 'Whoa... that was weird' reaction, and then the same basic thing happened in the fight between Momo and the Princess, and one of them said something like "That was disconcerting..."   And, technically, the train wreck scene was  Menou's imagination of what might have happened... at least that's my take on it. If we see the scene from Akari's point of view at some point we'll know for sure I guess.   There is one thing I wonder about with the crusade the Church has against Otherworlders with Pure Concepts. If ALL Pure Concepts eventually corrupt the person, how did their society get influenced so strongly by Japanese culture and language? It seems like, if the otherworlders were always so unstable, they wouldn't have had the type of impact on the world that they did to influence so much of their culture. This says to me that the church is actually reacting to the few extreme cases... the Great Human Errors... and eliminating ALL otherworlders in order to prevent any more catastrophes of that magnitude, when it is possible that some otherworlders might be able to remain stable with their Pure Concepts and not lose control.   I'm guessing that is the direction Menou's thoughts will be heading in the story at least... since Akari seems to be a girl that has already lived through some heavy stuff and maintained a positive outlook on life and might be the type that won't appear to be corrupted by repeated use of her powers, or suspected repeated use of her powers since Menou won't really know that they were used since it will be to save her life every time.      Back to top                  Aerodynamic41    Joined: 20 Oct 2015 		    Posts: 136       Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 11:39 am            I absolutely love the LN and the adaptation is looking great so far. I'm really excited to see how the anime will depict spoiler[Akari's real personality]. Back to top                  Nev999    Joined: 05 Aug 2021 		    Posts: 31       Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 1:37 pm              thadec wrote:    Proposing that James Beckett not be allowed to review any isekai titles in the future, or really shonen shows in general. It seems that Beckett has a real disdain towards the target audience - or at least what that audience likes and why - and will not be objective.            And I propose that he should be allowed to review whatever he wants, which I imagine will continue to happen. I've been following ANN for a while, and considering he really liked JJK (way more than I did), did super in-depth adoring reviews on AoT (which personally just allowed me to see that the show was continuing not to be my thing at all but I admired his passion) and his criticisms of Demon Slayer were pretty mild, it's just that fanbase is ridiculous, I never got the impression he doesn't like shonen or doesn't fall into its audience at all. And he's suited just fine for this series, as the reason people are interested in THIS show is because it's offering a bit of a twist on the isekai premise, and that seems to be what he was hooked by as well. This review focused on whether the show itself held together beyond that initial hook, and offered a fair assessment.   And honestly, considering you criticized the main character of this show and its fandom despite admitting not even watching the first episode in the Premiere thread, I don't think you personally have much room to talk about how it's bad to approach something with preconceived notions or disdain for the target audience.   For me, I think what will make or break this show is how Akari holds up as a character, and if her deal and her relationship with Menou deepens wants she finds out about Menou's hidden agenda. If she's what she appears on the surface, or they're just leaning on tropes with her, the central relationship won't be dynamic enough to carry the show, so I'm also hoping that hint about not wanting to be left behind means we'll get some good character writing and reason to root for this dynamic. There were quite a few moments in the eps that made me roll my eyes, but enough mystery and intrigue and potential in the plot I'm willing to keep going. Plus, I'm trash for girls being cool action heroes and gay with each other, I won't lie.      Back to top                  Florete    Joined: 21 Jan 2018 		    Posts: 259       Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 3:06 pm            The novels of this series are what got me to start taking notes on what I read, just to make sure I can keep track of all that is and has been going on.   Funny how, from what I'm seeing, the critics are liking this more than the fans. Perhaps seeing their precious self-insert potato-kun get a murder done on him was triggering.      Back to top                  Thesarum    Joined: 25 Mar 2022 		    Posts: 14       Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 4:40 pm            Serious bad vibes from Mother Superior. Quite aside from the obviously ominous name of "Archbishop Orwell" and the fact that any time a western church (i.e. Catholic/Anglican in its structure and iconography) is depicted in anime they're generally bad news. There's a whole pile of secrets awaiting us (and, by the looks of things, Menou) there. I think the fact that Menou will have her faith in the church challenged is fairly obvious. It'd be more of a twist if she didn't and it was just a straight up choice of betraying them for Akari.   Akari seems to have her share of secrets too, which is great. The bubbly crushing-on-Menou personality is plenty fun, but could outstay its welcome fairly easily.   Enjoying this so far, and there's plenty of promise.      Back to top                  Covnam    Joined: 31 May 2005 		    Posts: 2871       Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 10:18 pm              Quote:    we all know that Menou is going to eventually start to question her role as Akari's murderer            That's the most predicable thing to happen (leading to her not trying to kill (or save as needed) Akari, and while I think that's probably what will happen, I hope the story goes in a different direction. I'm enjoying it so far, but not interested in seeing the usual tropes, so fingers crossed   Stopping the train that way was odd. The engine was going full tilt, but instead of shutting off the engine, they just slowed the train by using a magic net (which, at that speed, probably would have caused the middle and rear cars of the train to derail at best (unless all the cars were also slowed by the magic?)) and somehow that caused it to turn off?      zensunni wrote:      And the train wreck scene at the end was NOT the first indication that Akari's pure concept had come into play during the episode. There was a moment, shortly before Akari interupted Menou's fight with the Red Knight when she attacked and then was back in position to attack again and had a 'Whoa... that was weird' reaction, and then the same basic thing happened in the fight between Momo and the Princess, and one of them said something like "That was disconcerting..."            I'm guessing those two moments are for the same event and are proof that time was rewound from the wreck we see at the end of the episode back to that point.      Back to top                  DRosencraft    Joined: 27 Apr 2010 		    Posts: 529       Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 11:10 pm              TarsTarkas wrote:    I like this series and I like the characters.  So looking at this one as a must see to the end.  I wonder if the anime adaptation will beat out the english light novels.   About Menou, while the anime shows her killing someone who probably deserves to die, we must remember spoiler[she and her group kill everyone who has that power/skill.  Guilt or innocence doesn't matter.  People who want to have normal lives within soceity and don't use their power/skill, are still hunted down and killed.  If you have been isekai'd, they will search for you, and they will kill you.  So even if you choose to be a good person and not use your power, you will still be killed.]  So Menou is a problematic character.  You can sympathize with her for her upbringing (brainwashing?) and despise her for her actions.   I like Momo too and can understand why she is the way she is.  Like Menou too.  Much discussion could be had on who is ultimately responsible and if really any justice can be had.  Probably not.            I've definitely already seen some people making that same mistake, if you want to call it a mistake, of not recognizing that Menou is at a minimum far more complicated than "hero stopping monsters" many want to paint her as out the gate. I haven't read the novels, but it's really obvious there are only a few directions things could be heading, an only a couple of them let her stay in the realm of any sort of heroic character - flawed or otherwise.    My sense of the "justice" issue is that, as it often turns out, it is a matter of stop diffing a deeper pit once you realize what's going on. My guess is that one or the other or both by the end will recognize that philosophy too late, or have given up on it despite realizing it. Title: EP. REVIEW: The Executioner and Her Way of Life [1/3] - Forum - Anime News Network:SEA
Data: Forum - View topicEP. REVIEW: The Executioner and Her Way of Life            Goto page 1, 2, 3  Next Note: this is the discussion thread for this article     Anime News Network Forum Index -> Site-related -> Talkback    View previous topic :: View next topic     Author Message        L'Imperatore    Joined: 24 Mar 2014 		    Posts: 514       Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 10:32 am            Same here, James. When Menou murdered this random isekai-ed dude, I'm sold        Back to top                  dm   Subscriber   Joined: 24 Sep 2010 		    Posts: 966       Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 10:44 am            The train-wreck scene was a great cap to the third episode, but the thing that caught my attention was when, in parting in the train car, Akari said "I don't want to be left alone again!", and Menou paused at the door to wonder, "Again?"   I wonder if this entire story maybe isn't Akari's first trip through this tale.      Back to top                  Rogueywon    Joined: 01 May 2011 		    Posts: 180       Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 11:03 am            My take on the light novels (the ones out in English at least) was that they're ambitious and high concept, but prone to getting muddled - so much stuff gong on to juggle - and dragged down by writing that was never really more than fair-to-middling. There's also an occasional tendancy towards excessive lore-dumping. The question is whether the adaptation can overcome those faults.    So far, it's looking good. The first three episodes definitely surpass the source in places.      Back to top                  RenimLS    Joined: 26 Mar 2014 		    Posts: 70 		    Location: North America 		        Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 11:17 am            I rather appreciate that the show is sometimes being more vague or less forthcoming on details than the LN.   It seems the show is set to really only cover them when it's necessary, which the LN tends to reveal more of its hand before it's actually necessary.  The way the LN introduces Akari you're actually in her headspace and get her thoughts on things before Menou appears.  spoiler[Which serves as a flag for the readers as her feelings and thoughts do not match up well with her behavior after meeting Menou], but it wasn't really necessary to have to go there.      Back to top                  zensunni    Joined: 05 Mar 2010 		    Posts: 1279       Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 11:19 am              dm wrote:    The train-wreck scene was a great cap to the third episode, but the thing that caught my attention was when, in parting in the train car, Akari said "I don't want to be left alone again!", and Menou paused at the door to wonder, "Again?"   I wonder if this entire story maybe isn't Akari's first trip through this tale.            Exactly! There was a huge hint there that Akari has either been through this all before OR her life in Japan featured abandonment and loneliness to spare. Perhaps this could have something to do with the dreams that Menou has about being in a classroom in Japan with her best friend who has Akari's outline waving at her? Is it possible that Menou is also not a native of this world, but also an otherworlder with a pure concept that is just as dangerous as Akari's?    And the train wreck scene at the end was NOT the first indication that Akari's pure concept had come into play during the episode. There was a moment, shortly before Akari interupted Menou's fight with the Red Knight when she attacked and then was back in position to attack again and had a 'Whoa... that was weird' reaction, and then the same basic thing happened in the fight between Momo and the Princess, and one of them said something like "That was disconcerting..."   And, technically, the train wreck scene was  Menou's imagination of what might have happened... at least that's my take on it. If we see the scene from Akari's point of view at some point we'll know for sure I guess.   There is one thing I wonder about with the crusade the Church has against Otherworlders with Pure Concepts. If ALL Pure Concepts eventually corrupt the person, how did their society get influenced so strongly by Japanese culture and language? It seems like, if the otherworlders were always so unstable, they wouldn't have had the type of impact on the world that they did to influence so much of their culture. This says to me that the church is actually reacting to the few extreme cases... the Great Human Errors... and eliminating ALL otherworlders in order to prevent any more catastrophes of that magnitude, when it is possible that some otherworlders might be able to remain stable with their Pure Concepts and not lose control.   I'm guessing that is the direction Menou's thoughts will be heading in the story at least... since Akari seems to be a girl that has already lived through some heavy stuff and maintained a positive outlook on life and might be the type that won't appear to be corrupted by repeated use of her powers, or suspected repeated use of her powers since Menou won't really know that they were used since it will be to save her life every time.      Back to top                  Aerodynamic41    Joined: 20 Oct 2015 		    Posts: 136       Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 11:39 am            I absolutely love the LN and the adaptation is looking great so far. I think the red knight didn't feel as dangerous as it was in the LN but that's a minor quibble. From the opening and the pacing, it looks like the anime will adapt until Volume 2. I'm really excited to see how the anime will depict spoiler[Akari's real personality]. I've been following ANN for a while, and considering he really liked JJK (way more than I did), did super in-depth adoring reviews on AoT (which personally just allowed me to see that the show was continuing not to be my thing at all but I admired his passion) and his criticisms of Demon Slayer were pretty mild, it's just that fanbase is ridiculous, I never got the impression he doesn't like shonen or doesn't fall into its audience at all. And he's suited just fine for this series, as the reason people are interested in THIS show is because it's offering a bit of a twist on the isekai premise, and that seems to be what he was hooked by as well. This review focused on whether the show itself held together beyond that initial hook, and offered a fair assessment.   And honestly, considering you criticized the main character of this show and its fandom despite admitting not even watching the first episode in the Premiere thread, I don't think you personally have much room to talk about how it's bad to approach something with preconceived notions or disdain for the target audience.   For me, I think what will make or break this show is how Akari holds up as a character, and if her deal and her relationship with Menou deepens wants she finds out about Menou's hidden agenda. If she's what she appears on the surface, or they're just leaning on tropes with her, the central relationship won't be dynamic enough to carry the show, so I'm also hoping that hint about not wanting to be left behind means we'll get some good character writing and reason to root for this dynamic. There were quite a few moments in the eps that made me roll my eyes, but enough mystery and intrigue and potential in the plot I'm willing to keep going. Plus, I'm trash for girls being cool action heroes and gay with each other, I won't lie.      Back to top                  Florete    Joined: 21 Jan 2018 		    Posts: 259       Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 3:06 pm            The novels of this series are what got me to start taking notes on what I read, just to make sure I can keep track of all that is and has been going on.   Funny how, from what I'm seeing, the critics are liking this more than the fans. Perhaps seeing their precious self-insert potato-kun get a murder done on him was triggering.      Back to top                  Thesarum    Joined: 25 Mar 2022 		    Posts: 14       Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 4:40 pm            Serious bad vibes from Mother Superior. Quite aside from the obviously ominous name of "Archbishop Orwell" and the fact that any time a western church (i.e. Catholic/Anglican in its structure and iconography) is depicted in anime they're generally bad news. There's a whole pile of secrets awaiting us (and, by the looks of things, Menou) there. I think the fact that Menou will have her faith in the church challenged is fairly obvious. It'd be more of a twist if she didn't and it was just a straight up choice of betraying them for Akari.   Akari seems to have her share of secrets too, which is great. The bubbly crushing-on-Menou personality is plenty fun, but could outstay its welcome fairly easily.   Enjoying this so far, and there's plenty of promise.      Back to top                  Covnam    Joined: 31 May 2005 		    Posts: 2871       Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 10:18 pm              Quote:    we all know that Menou is going to eventually start to question her role as Akari's murderer            That's the most predicable thing to happen (leading to her not trying to kill (or save as needed) Akari, and while I think that's probably what will happen, I hope the story goes in a different direction. I'm enjoying it so far, but not interested in seeing the usual tropes, so fingers crossed   Stopping the train that way was odd. The engine was going full tilt, but instead of shutting off the engine, they just slowed the train by using a magic net (which, at that speed, probably would have caused the middle and rear cars of the train to derail at best (unless all the cars were also slowed by the magic?)) and somehow that caused it to turn off?      zensunni wrote:      And the train wreck scene at the end was NOT the first indication that Akari's pure concept had come into play during the episode. There was a moment, shortly before Akari interupted Menou's fight with the Red Knight when she attacked and then was back in position to attack again and had a 'Whoa... that was weird' reaction, and then the same basic thing happened in the fight between Momo and the Princess, and one of them said something like "That was disconcerting..."            I'm guessing those two moments are for the same event and are proof that time was rewound from the wreck we see at the end of the episode back to that point.      Back to top                  DRosencraft    Joined: 27 Apr 2010 		    Posts: 529       Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 11:10 pm              TarsTarkas wrote:    I like this series and I like the characters.  So looking at this one as a must see to the end.  I wonder if the anime adaptation will beat out the english light novels.   About Menou, while the anime shows her killing someone who probably deserves to die, we must remember spoiler[she and her group kill everyone who has that power/skill.  Guilt or innocence doesn't matter.  People who want to have normal lives within soceity and don't use their power/skill, are still hunted down and killed.  If you have been isekai'd, they will search for you, and they will kill you.  So even if you choose to be a good person and not use your power, you will still be killed.]  So Menou is a problematic character.  You can sympathize with her for her upbringing (brainwashing?) and despise her for her actions.   I like Momo too and can understand why she is the way she is.  Like Menou too.  Much discussion could be had on who is ultimately responsible and if really any justice can be had.  Probably not.            I've definitely already seen some people making that same mistake, if you want to call it a mistake, of not recognizing that Menou is at a minimum far more complicated than "hero stopping monsters" many want to paint her as out the gate. I haven't read the novels, but it's really obvious there are only a few directions things could be heading, an only a couple of them let her stay in the realm of any sort of heroic character - flawed or otherwise.    My sense of the "justice" issue is that, as it often turns out, it is a matter of stop diffing a deeper pit once you realize what's going on. My guess is that one or the other or both by the end will recognize that philosophy too late, or have given up on it despite realizing it. Title: EP. REVIEW: The Executioner and Her Way of Life [1/3] - Forum - Anime News Network:SEA
Data: Goto page 1, 2, 3  Next Note: this is the discussion thread for this article     Anime News Network Forum Index -> Site-related -> Talkback    View previous topic :: View next topic     Author Message        L'Imperatore    Joined: 24 Mar 2014 		    Posts: 514       Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 10:32 am            Same here, James. When Menou murdered this random isekai-ed dude, I'm sold        Back to top                  dm   Subscriber   Joined: 24 Sep 2010 		    Posts: 966       Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 10:44 am            The train-wreck scene was a great cap to the third episode, but the thing that caught my attention was when, in parting in the train car, Akari said "I don't want to be left alone again!", and Menou paused at the door to wonder, "Again?"   I wonder if this entire story maybe isn't Akari's first trip through this tale.      Back to top                  Rogueywon    Joined: 01 May 2011 		    Posts: 180       Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 11:03 am            My take on the light novels (the ones out in English at least) was that they're ambitious and high concept, but prone to getting muddled - so much stuff gong on to juggle - and dragged down by writing that was never really more than fair-to-middling. There's also an occasional tendancy towards excessive lore-dumping. The question is whether the adaptation can overcome those faults.    So far, it's looking good. The first three episodes definitely surpass the source in places.      Back to top                  RenimLS    Joined: 26 Mar 2014 		    Posts: 70 		    Location: North America 		        Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 11:17 am            I rather appreciate that the show is sometimes being more vague or less forthcoming on details than the LN.   It seems the show is set to really only cover them when it's necessary, which the LN tends to reveal more of its hand before it's actually necessary.  The way the LN introduces Akari you're actually in her headspace and get her thoughts on things before Menou appears.  spoiler[Which serves as a flag for the readers as her feelings and thoughts do not match up well with her behavior after meeting Menou], but it wasn't really necessary to have to go there.      Back to top                  zensunni    Joined: 05 Mar 2010 		    Posts: 1279       Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 11:19 am              dm wrote:    The train-wreck scene was a great cap to the third episode, but the thing that caught my attention was when, in parting in the train car, Akari said "I don't want to be left alone again!", and Menou paused at the door to wonder, "Again?"   I wonder if this entire story maybe isn't Akari's first trip through this tale.            Exactly! There was a huge hint there that Akari has either been through this all before OR her life in Japan featured abandonment and loneliness to spare. Perhaps this could have something to do with the dreams that Menou has about being in a classroom in Japan with her best friend who has Akari's outline waving at her? Is it possible that Menou is also not a native of this world, but also an otherworlder with a pure concept that is just as dangerous as Akari's?    And the train wreck scene at the end was NOT the first indication that Akari's pure concept had come into play during the episode. There was a moment, shortly before Akari interupted Menou's fight with the Red Knight when she attacked and then was back in position to attack again and had a 'Whoa... that was weird' reaction, and then the same basic thing happened in the fight between Momo and the Princess, and one of them said something like "That was disconcerting..."   And, technically, the train wreck scene was  Menou's imagination of what might have happened... at least that's my take on it. If we see the scene from Akari's point of view at some point we'll know for sure I guess.   There is one thing I wonder about with the crusade the Church has against Otherworlders with Pure Concepts. If ALL Pure Concepts eventually corrupt the person, how did their society get influenced so strongly by Japanese culture and language? It seems like, if the otherworlders were always so unstable, they wouldn't have had the type of impact on the world that they did to influence so much of their culture. This says to me that the church is actually reacting to the few extreme cases... the Great Human Errors... and eliminating ALL otherworlders in order to prevent any more catastrophes of that magnitude, when it is possible that some otherworlders might be able to remain stable with their Pure Concepts and not lose control.   I'm guessing that is the direction Menou's thoughts will be heading in the story at least... since Akari seems to be a girl that has already lived through some heavy stuff and maintained a positive outlook on life and might be the type that won't appear to be corrupted by repeated use of her powers, or suspected repeated use of her powers since Menou won't really know that they were used since it will be to save her life every time.      Back to top                  Aerodynamic41    Joined: 20 Oct 2015 		    Posts: 136       Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 11:39 am            I absolutely love the LN and the adaptation is looking great so far. I think the red knight didn't feel as dangerous as it was in the LN but that's a minor quibble. From the opening and the pacing, it looks like the anime will adapt until Volume 2. I'm really excited to see how the anime will depict spoiler[Akari's real personality].      Back to top                  thadec    Joined: 02 Apr 2022 		    Posts: 37       Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 11:45 am            Proposing that James Beckett not be allowed to review any isekai titles in the future, or really shonen shows in general. It seems that Beckett has a real disdain towards the target audience - or at least what that audience likes and why - and will not be objective.      Back to top                  FilthyCasual    Joined: 01 Jun 2015 		    Posts: 1692       Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 11:46 am            It's nice to have a refreshingly Light Novel Energy LN adaptation.  Dead Detective did its best, but the production values and plotting crumpled; fingers crossed this one goes the distance.  Presumably Akari will be something other than Nice, Existent, and Increasingly Down Bad once she gets shipped off to church.     Menou and Momo are great, though.  Especially poor Momo, doomed to lose to BSS.      Back to top                  dm   Subscriber   Joined: 24 Sep 2010 		    Posts: 966       Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 1:00 pm              zensunni wrote:    And the train wreck scene at the end was NOT the first indication that Akari's pure concept had come into play during the episode. There was a moment, shortly before Akari interupted Menou's fight with the Red Knight when she attacked and then was back in position to attack again and had a 'Whoa... that was weird' reaction, and then the same basic thing happened in the fight between Momo and the Princess, and one of them said something like "That was disconcerting..."            I interpreted the train-wreck scene at the end as the explanation for the time-stutter in the fight with the Red Knight (and the "simultaneous" scene between Momo and the Princess) --- that was the moment Akari reset the timeline to.     Quote:    And, technically, the train wreck scene was  Menou's imagination of what might have happened... at least that's my take on it. If we see the scene from Akari's point of view at some point we'll know for sure I guess.            Given that I think Menou's vision provides an explanation for the time-stutter earlier in the episode, I interpret it as a memory of the original timeline.      Back to top                  TarsTarkas    Joined: 20 Dec 2007 		    Posts: 5327 		    Location: Virginia, United States 		        Posted: Mon Apr 18, 2022 1:36 pm            I like this series and I like the characters. Title: EP. REVIEW: The Executioner and Her Way of Life [1/3] - Forum - Anime News Network:SEA
Data: I absolutely love the LN and the adaptation is looking great so far. I think the red knight didn't feel as dangerous as it was in the LN but that's a minor quibble. From the opening and the pacing, it looks like the anime will adapt until Volume 2. I'm really excited to see how the anime will depict spoiler[Akari's real personality].

Title: EP. REVIEW: The Executioner and Her Way of Life [1/3] - Forum - Anime News Network:SEA
Data: I like this series and I like the characters.  So looking at this one as a must see to the end.  I wonder if the anime adaptation will beat out the english light novels.   About Menou, while the anime shows her killing someone who probably deserves to die, we must remember spoiler[she and her group kill everyone who has that power/skill.  Guilt or innocence doesn't matter.  People who want to have normal lives within soceity and don't use their power/skill, are still hunted down and killed.  If you have been isekai'd, they will search for you, and they will kill you.  So even if you choose to be a good person and not use your power, you will still be killed.]  So Menou is a problematic character.  You can sympathize with her for her upbringing (brainwashing?) and despise her for her actions.   I like Momo too and can understand why she is the way she is.  Like Menou too.  Much discussion could be had on who is ultimately responsible and if really any justice can be had.  Probably not.

Title: EP. REVIEW: The Executioner and Her Way of Life [1/3] - Forum - Anime News Network:SEA
Data: Serious bad vibes from Mother Superior. Quite aside from the obviously ominous name of "Archbishop Orwell" and the fact that any time a western church (i.e. Catholic/Anglican in its structure and iconography) is depicted in anime they're generally bad news. There's a whole pile of secrets awaiting us (and, by the looks of things, Menou) there. I think the fact that Menou will have her faith in the church challenged is fairly obvious. It'd be more of a twist if she didn't and it was just a straight up choice of betraying them for Akari.   Akari seems to have her share of secrets too, which is great. The bubbly crushing-on-Menou personality is plenty fun, but could outstay its welcome fairly easily.   Enjoying this so far, and there's plenty of promise.

Forum - View topicNEWS: Sonic the Hedgehog 2 Film Stays at #2 in U.S., Crosses US$145 Million             Note: this is the discussion thread for this article     Anime News Network Forum Index -> Site-related -> Talkback    View previous topic :: View next topic     Author Message        Psajdak    Joined: 12 Oct 2008 		    Posts: 465       Posted: Mon Apr 25, 2022 8:51 am            Are we living in the age of Sonic renaissance?      Back to top                  Silver Kirin    Joined: 09 Aug 2018 		    Posts: 631       Posted: Mon Apr 25, 2022 12:11 pm              Psajdak wrote:    Are we living in the age of Sonic renaissance?           I would say that it's difficult to determine, in regards to Sonic's video game presence it could be argued that Sonic Mania brought back the character to the gaming world after the disaster that was Sonic Boom, but due to Forces and Colors Ultimate general bad reception amongst gamers I think his future in gaming is still up in the air unless Frontiers exceeds all expectations.  In terms of Sonic's popularity outside the videogame realm I'd say that we're truly living a renaissance. As opposed to the games' reception Boom's cartoon was enjoyable, Sonic made some fun cameos in Wreck-it-Ralph 1 and 2, he got a special appearance in OK K.O, the new Sonic comic seems to be doing great, there's that Netflix show in development, and Sonic's movie has become a franchise at Paramount.  I think it could be argued that Sonic has become more of multimedia IP and not just a videogame icon, kids these days are probably more familiar with Sonic by his appearances in other media than his own videogames, I mean I have two nephews that love Sonic but never played any of his games, I tried making them play the original Genesis game but they couldn't pass the first enemy      Back to top                  Mr. sickVisionz    Joined: 28 Oct 2007 		    Posts: 2124       Posted: Mon Apr 25, 2022 8:09 pm              Quote:    Ben Schwartz (DuckTales, Parks and Recreation) voiced the title character Sonic in the original film.            Did they change the VA for this one? Forum - View topicNEWS: Sonic the Hedgehog 2 Film Stays at #2 in U.S., Crosses US$145 Million             Note: this is the discussion thread for this article     Anime News Network Forum Index -> Site-related -> Talkback    View previous topic :: View next topic     Author Message        Psajdak    Joined: 12 Oct 2008 		    Posts: 465       Posted: Mon Apr 25, 2022 8:51 am            Are we living in the age of Sonic renaissance?      Back to top                  Silver Kirin    Joined: 09 Aug 2018 		    Posts: 631       Posted: Mon Apr 25, 2022 12:11 pm              Psajdak wrote:    Are we living in the age of Sonic renaissance?           I would say that it's difficult to determine, in regards to Sonic's video game presence it could be argued that Sonic Mania brought back the character to the gaming world after the disaster that was Sonic Boom, but due to Forces and Colors Ultimate general bad reception amongst gamers I think his future in gaming is still up in the air unless Frontiers exceeds all expectations.  In terms of Sonic's popularity outside the videogame realm I'd say that we're truly living a renaissance. As opposed to the games' reception Boom's cartoon was enjoyable, Sonic made some fun cameos in Wreck-it-Ralph 1 and 2, he got a special appearance in OK K.O, the new Sonic comic seems to be doing great, there's that Netflix show in development, and Sonic's movie has become a franchise at Paramount.  I think it could be argued that Sonic has become more of multimedia IP and not just a videogame icon, kids these days are probably more familiar with Sonic by his appearances in other media than his own videogames, I mean I have two nephews that love Sonic but never played any of his games, I tried making them play the original Genesis game but they couldn't pass the first enemy      Back to top                  Mr. sickVisionz    Joined: 28 Oct 2007 		    Posts: 2124       Posted: Mon Apr 25, 2022 8:09 pm              Quote:    Ben Schwartz (DuckTales, Parks and Recreation) voiced the title character Sonic in the original film.            Did they change the VA for this one? Forum - View topicNEWS: Sonic the Hedgehog 2 Film Stays at #2 in U.S., Crosses US$145 Million             Note: this is the discussion thread for this article     Anime News Network Forum Index -> Site-related -> Talkback    View previous topic :: View next topic     Author Message        Psajdak    Joined: 12 Oct 2008 		    Posts: 465       Posted: Mon Apr 25, 2022 8:51 am            Are we living in the age of Sonic renaissance?      Back to top                  Silver Kirin    Joined: 09 Aug 2018 		    Posts: 631       Posted: Mon Apr 25, 2022 12:11 pm              Psajdak wrote:    Are we living in the age of Sonic renaissance?           I would say that it's difficult to determine, in regards to Sonic's video game presence it could be argued that Sonic Mania brought back the character to the gaming world after the disaster that was Sonic Boom, but due to Forces and Colors Ultimate general bad reception amongst gamers I think his future in gaming is still up in the air unless Frontiers exceeds all expectations.  In terms of Sonic's popularity outside the videogame realm I'd say that we're truly living a renaissance. As opposed to the games' reception Boom's cartoon was enjoyable, Sonic made some fun cameos in Wreck-it-Ralph 1 and 2, he got a special appearance in OK K.O, the new Sonic comic seems to be doing great, there's that Netflix show in development, and Sonic's movie has become a franchise at Paramount.  I think it could be argued that Sonic has become more of multimedia IP and not just a videogame icon, kids these days are probably more familiar with Sonic by his appearances in other media than his own videogames, I mean I have two nephews that love Sonic but never played any of his games, I tried making them play the original Genesis game but they couldn't pass the first enemy      Back to top                  Mr. sickVisionz    Joined: 28 Oct 2007 		    Posts: 2124       Posted: Mon Apr 25, 2022 8:09 pm              Quote:    Ben Schwartz (DuckTales, Parks and Recreation) voiced the title character Sonic in the original film.            Did they change the VA for this one? REVIEW: Aharen-san wa Hakarenai             Note: this is the discussion thread for this article     Anime News Network Forum Index -> Site-related -> Talkback    View previous topic :: View next topic     Author Message        Tanteikingdomkey    Joined: 03 Sep 2008 		    Posts: 2294       Posted: Sat Apr 16, 2022 11:45 pm            Sooo just figured I'd ask, since based on the first episode it seemed very obvious.    Is Aharen San supposed to be viewed as being on the autism spectrum? Because a lot of her behavior reminds me a lot of people who are on the spectrum      Back to top                   MFrontier    Joined: 13 Apr 2014 		    Posts: 3984       Posted: Sun Apr 17, 2022 11:36 am            This show is really sold on the comedic interplay between Raido and Aharen, with Raid's wholesome personality, ditziness, and flights of fancy, and Aharen being so stoic, exaggerated, and yet oddly sweet. Takuma Terashima and Inori Minase also play off each other very well.    I also love how they went ahead and did a full ED sequence on Aharen's dance.      Back to top                  omnistry    Joined: 03 Mar 2005 		    Posts: 993       Posted: Sun Apr 17, 2022 2:08 pm              Tanteikingdomkey wrote:    Sooo just figured I'd ask, since based on the first episode it seemed very obvious.    Is Aharen San supposed to be viewed as being on the autism spectrum? Because a lot of her behavior reminds me a lot of people who are on the spectrum            Chiming in, as someone who is on the Spectrum.   I would say no to her being Autistic, as most women who get it tend to be on the very low end of the Spectrum (non-verbal, violent fits, biting). Aharen shows none of those aspects. She could have Asperger’s, but definitely not straight-up Autism.      Back to top                   flamemasterelan    Joined: 17 Apr 2022 		    Posts: 3       Posted: Sun Apr 17, 2022 4:06 pm              omnistry wrote:       Tanteikingdomkey wrote:    Sooo just figured I'd ask, since based on the first episode it seemed very obvious.    Is Aharen San supposed to be viewed as being on the autism spectrum? Because a lot of her behavior reminds me a lot of people who are on the spectrum            Chiming in, as someone who is on the Spectrum.   I would say no to her being Autistic, as most women who get it tend to be on the very low end of the Spectrum (non-verbal, violent fits, biting). Aharen shows none of those aspects. She could have Asperger’s, but definitely not straight-up Autism.           Asperger's Syndrome doesn't technically exist anymore. It's been folded into the general Autism Spectrum Disorder, or ASD as of 2013 (in the US), and 2022 (worldwide). Also, the argument that women tend to be on the low end of the spectrum strikes me as rather off, to say the least. Women "hide" their symptoms better than men because society expects them to. It's not abnormal for men to be bad at communication, or be bad at expressing/reading emotion or social cues. But it's considered an aberration for a woman to do so, and they're forced to adapt, so their symptoms don't display the same way.   As far as the OP goes, Aharen does have neuro divergent traits, but they're almost definitely not going to be acknowledged as anything more than her personality.      Back to top                  Gina Szanboti    Joined: 03 Aug 2008 		    Posts: 10251       Posted: Sat Apr 23, 2022 2:57 pm            The two best parts of this episode for me were the serial escalation in "they can't possibly get any closer than that!" and Raido of all people having the lack of self-awareness to show Aharen how to smile and show emotions.  Still, that teeny tiny upturn he managed did melt my heart.      Back to top                  MFrontier    Joined: 13 Apr 2014 		    Posts: 3984       Posted: Sat Apr 23, 2022 11:36 pm            Kana Hanazawa as a classical literature teacher who gets all hot and bothered by the courtly romance of Aharen and Raido was something I didn't know I needed.   So much great comedy moments...Raido inconsolable after the movie (even Aharen cried!), the freestyle rapping communicating, fidget-spinner Aharen and Raido being worried about her future, Raido worried that everything was trying to kill them, and Raido trying to save face after losing to a little girl in Reversi.   Also look at Aharen trying to support childhood friend romances!   Aharen summoning her dog to carry her is the most Aharen-thing ever. REVIEW: Aharen-san wa Hakarenai             Note: this is the discussion thread for this article     Anime News Network Forum Index -> Site-related -> Talkback    View previous topic :: View next topic     Author Message        Tanteikingdomkey    Joined: 03 Sep 2008 		    Posts: 2294       Posted: Sat Apr 16, 2022 11:45 pm            Sooo just figured I'd ask, since based on the first episode it seemed very obvious.    Is Aharen San supposed to be viewed as being on the autism spectrum? Because a lot of her behavior reminds me a lot of people who are on the spectrum      Back to top                   MFrontier    Joined: 13 Apr 2014 		    Posts: 3984       Posted: Sun Apr 17, 2022 11:36 am            This show is really sold on the comedic interplay between Raido and Aharen, with Raid's wholesome personality, ditziness, and flights of fancy, and Aharen being so stoic, exaggerated, and yet oddly sweet. Takuma Terashima and Inori Minase also play off each other very well.    I also love how they went ahead and did a full ED sequence on Aharen's dance.      Back to top                  omnistry    Joined: 03 Mar 2005 		    Posts: 993       Posted: Sun Apr 17, 2022 2:08 pm              Tanteikingdomkey wrote:    Sooo just figured I'd ask, since based on the first episode it seemed very obvious.    Is Aharen San supposed to be viewed as being on the autism spectrum? Because a lot of her behavior reminds me a lot of people who are on the spectrum            Chiming in, as someone who is on the Spectrum.   I would say no to her being Autistic, as most women who get it tend to be on the very low end of the Spectrum (non-verbal, violent fits, biting). Aharen shows none of those aspects. She could have Asperger’s, but definitely not straight-up Autism.      Back to top                   flamemasterelan    Joined: 17 Apr 2022 		    Posts: 3       Posted: Sun Apr 17, 2022 4:06 pm              omnistry wrote:       Tanteikingdomkey wrote:    Sooo just figured I'd ask, since based on the first episode it seemed very obvious.    Is Aharen San supposed to be viewed as being on the autism spectrum? Because a lot of her behavior reminds me a lot of people who are on the spectrum            Chiming in, as someone who is on the Spectrum.   I would say no to her being Autistic, as most women who get it tend to be on the very low end of the Spectrum (non-verbal, violent fits, biting). Aharen shows none of those aspects. She could have Asperger’s, but definitely not straight-up Autism.           Asperger's Syndrome doesn't technically exist anymore. It's been folded into the general Autism Spectrum Disorder, or ASD as of 2013 (in the US), and 2022 (worldwide). Also, the argument that women tend to be on the low end of the spectrum strikes me as rather off, to say the least. Women "hide" their symptoms better than men because society expects them to. It's not abnormal for men to be bad at communication, or be bad at expressing/reading emotion or social cues. But it's considered an aberration for a woman to do so, and they're forced to adapt, so their symptoms don't display the same way.   As far as the OP goes, Aharen does have neuro divergent traits, but they're almost definitely not going to be acknowledged as anything more than her personality.      Back to top                  Gina Szanboti    Joined: 03 Aug 2008 		    Posts: 10251       Posted: Sat Apr 23, 2022 2:57 pm            The two best parts of this episode for me were the serial escalation in "they can't possibly get any closer than that!" and Raido of all people having the lack of self-awareness to show Aharen how to smile and show emotions.  Still, that teeny tiny upturn he managed did melt my heart.      Back to top                  MFrontier    Joined: 13 Apr 2014 		    Posts: 3984       Posted: Sat Apr 23, 2022 11:36 pm            Kana Hanazawa as a classical literature teacher who gets all hot and bothered by the courtly romance of Aharen and Raido was something I didn't know I needed.   So much great comedy moments...Raido inconsolable after the movie (even Aharen cried!), the freestyle rapping communicating, fidget-spinner Aharen and Raido being worried about her future, Raido worried that everything was trying to kill them, and Raido trying to save face after losing to a little girl in Reversi.   Also look at Aharen trying to support childhood friend romances!   Aharen summoning her dog to carry her is the most Aharen-thing ever. REVIEW: Aharen-san wa Hakarenai             Note: this is the discussion thread for this article     Anime News Network Forum Index -> Site-related -> Talkback    View previous topic :: View next topic     Author Message        Tanteikingdomkey    Joined: 03 Sep 2008 		    Posts: 2294       Posted: Sat Apr 16, 2022 11:45 pm            Sooo just figured I'd ask, since based on the first episode it seemed very obvious.    Is Aharen San supposed to be viewed as being on the autism spectrum? Because a lot of her behavior reminds me a lot of people who are on the spectrum      Back to top                   MFrontier    Joined: 13 Apr 2014 		    Posts: 3984       Posted: Sun Apr 17, 2022 11:36 am            This show is really sold on the comedic interplay between Raido and Aharen, with Raid's wholesome personality, ditziness, and flights of fancy, and Aharen being so stoic, exaggerated, and yet oddly sweet. Takuma Terashima and Inori Minase also play off each other very well.    I also love how they went ahead and did a full ED sequence on Aharen's dance.      Back to top                  omnistry    Joined: 03 Mar 2005 		    Posts: 993       Posted: Sun Apr 17, 2022 2:08 pm              Tanteikingdomkey wrote:    Sooo just figured I'd ask, since based on the first episode it seemed very obvious.    Is Aharen San supposed to be viewed as being on the autism spectrum? Because a lot of her behavior reminds me a lot of people who are on the spectrum            Chiming in, as someone who is on the Spectrum.   I would say no to her being Autistic, as most women who get it tend to be on the very low end of the Spectrum (non-verbal, violent fits, biting). Aharen shows none of those aspects. She could have Asperger’s, but definitely not straight-up Autism.      Back to top                   flamemasterelan    Joined: 17 Apr 2022 		    Posts: 3       Posted: Sun Apr 17, 2022 4:06 pm              omnistry wrote:       Tanteikingdomkey wrote:    Sooo just figured I'd ask, since based on the first episode it seemed very obvious.    Is Aharen San supposed to be viewed as being on the autism spectrum? Because a lot of her behavior reminds me a lot of people who are on the spectrum            Chiming in, as someone who is on the Spectrum.   I would say no to her being Autistic, as most women who get it tend to be on the very low end of the Spectrum (non-verbal, violent fits, biting). Aharen shows none of those aspects. She could have Asperger’s, but definitely not straight-up Autism.           Asperger's Syndrome doesn't technically exist anymore. It's been folded into the general Autism Spectrum Disorder, or ASD as of 2013 (in the US), and 2022 (worldwide). Also, the argument that women tend to be on the low end of the spectrum strikes me as rather off, to say the least. Women "hide" their symptoms better than men because society expects them to. It's not abnormal for men to be bad at communication, or be bad at expressing/reading emotion or social cues. But it's considered an aberration for a woman to do so, and they're forced to adapt, so their symptoms don't display the same way.   As far as the OP goes, Aharen does have neuro divergent traits, but they're almost definitely not going to be acknowledged as anything more than her personality.      Back to top                  Gina Szanboti    Joined: 03 Aug 2008 		    Posts: 10251       Posted: Sat Apr 23, 2022 2:57 pm            The two best parts of this episode for me were the serial escalation in "they can't possibly get any closer than that!" and Raido of all people having the lack of self-awareness to show Aharen how to smile and show emotions.  Still, that teeny tiny upturn he managed did melt my heart.      Back to top                  MFrontier    Joined: 13 Apr 2014 		    Posts: 3984       Posted: Sat Apr 23, 2022 11:36 pm            Kana Hanazawa as a classical literature teacher who gets all hot and bothered by the courtly romance of Aharen and Raido was something I didn't know I needed.   So much great comedy moments...Raido inconsolable after the movie (even Aharen cried!), the freestyle rapping communicating, fidget-spinner Aharen and Raido being worried about her future, Raido worried that everything was trying to kill them, and Raido trying to save face after losing to a little girl in Reversi.   Also look at Aharen trying to support childhood friend romances!   Aharen summoning her dog to carry her is the most Aharen-thing ever. Forum - View topicREVIEW: Sakamoto Days GN 1             Note: this is the discussion thread for this article     Anime News Network Forum Index -> Site-related -> Talkback    View previous topic :: View next topic     Author Message        wolf10    Joined: 23 Jan 2016 		    Posts: 706       Posted: Sun Apr 24, 2022 1:28 pm            This is one of the few new Jump series I've fallen for that didn't get the axe at the two-volume mark, and it's only gotten better at constant escalation. It's been the highlight of my Sunday morning for about a year now. (Speaking of which, the new chapter is out...)   Shin is a good boy. Lu is a good girl. Sakamoto is best team dad. (Even though he's apparently supposed to be younger than me. I feel old now.) The SPYxFAMILY parallels are a lot more obvious to me now that the anime has started, but knowing that now doesn't diminish how much fun I've had with it overall. The way Shin's mind-reading is integrated with the paneling is probably my favorite running gag. He is our fourth wall.     Quote:    − Fat jokes aren't necessary         Without delving into spoiler territory, you (and anyone else snagging on that particular note) may be relieved to know that the series does eventually take a different stance on Sakamoto's weight.
